titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana: General Ephemera
Speck (William A.) Collection of Goetheana: General Ephemera
titlestmt.author: by Christa Sammons

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday March 22, 2019 at 03:01

did.unittitle: William A. Speck collection of Goetheana : general ephemera

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana: General Ephemera is an artificial collection of miscellaneous, non-book materials long associated with the Speck Collection but previously uncataloged. The collection demonstrates how Goethe and his works entered into the popular culture in the late nineteenth century and early decades of the twentieth. The collection includes a few items relating directly to Goethe, such as pens that he used and his grandfather Textor's seal, as well as items intended for the tourist market, probably purchased in the streets of Weimar around the turn of the twentieth century. Printed ephemera in the collection includes inflation money from the 1920s, or "Notgeld," printed with quotations from Goethe and illustrations from his works; advertising trade cards and other advertising materials; posters; cigar boxes; matchbooks; stationery; postcards; photographs of actors in Goethe-related roles; and wall hangings. Three-dimensional items include figurines of characters from Faust, plaques featuring Goethe's image, a fragment of his house, pressed flowers from his garden, and a lock of Schiller's hair.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in German; some materials in English.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired at various times and from various sources.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The Speck Collection of Goetheana: General Ephemera consists chiefly of material that has long been associated with the William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana but has never before been cataloged. A significant portion of the material came to the library as part of the Faust collection assembled by George Wilhelm Heinrich Ehrhardt and acquired by William A. Speck in 1923. While much of that collection was cataloged, some remained in various "miscellaneous" files or "object" boxes. (Ehrhardt items usually bear tiny stickers with a number in ink in a German hand.) Other items seem to have been saved by Speck or sent to him and his successors because people knew of their obsessive interest in Goethe—postage stamps, advertising trade cards, clippings, post cards. The provenance of particular items, when known, has been recorded in the list of collection contents.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana: General Ephemera is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana: General Ephemera . Yale Collection of German Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Christa Sammons, Curator of the Yale Collection of German Literature, made a preliminary contents list and wrote the description of the collection in 2009. During processing, the curator discarded a few severely damaged items of little apparent worth, and placed elsewhere a few items that had no relevance to Goethe or German literature. The material was then rehoused and the list standardized into its current form.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Associated Materials: William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana: Manuscripts (YCGL MSS 6), William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana: Music (YCGL MSS 9), William A. Speck Collection of Prints (YCGL MSS 11), William A. Speck collection of Goetheana: Theater Ephemera (YCGL MSS 24), and William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana: Original Artwork (YCGL MSS 26), Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: William A. Speck (1864-1928)
bioghist.p: William A. Speck, the son of German immigrants, was born in New York City in 1864. A pharmacist by profession, he amassed the largest Goethe collection outside of Germany. In 1913, he and his collection came from Haverstraw, New York to Yale, where he served as curator of the Speck Collection until his death in 1928. For further biographical information on William A. Speck and a general history and description of the Speck Collection, see the finding aid for the William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana: Manuscripts (YCGL MSS 6).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana: General Ephemera is an artificial collection of miscellaneous, non-book materials long associated with the Speck Collection but previously uncataloged. These are artifacts that were not considered important enough to catalog separately or to include in the William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana: Original Artwork. The quality and interest of the material vary widely. There are historical souvenirs of some significance, such as pens used by Goethe or his grandfather Textor's seal, as well as cheap tourist items, probably purchased in the streets of Weimar around the turn of the twentieth century. The inflation money printed the 1920s is oddly moving: in the throes of an economic crisis that wiped out fortunes large and small, German cities and towns adorned their "Notgeld" with quotations from Goethe and illustrations from his works. Some of the items in the collection could be loved only by the dedicated Goethe afficionado—the illustration of his coach, for instance, or the pressed flowers from his garden, gathered decades after his death.

If the collection has significance, it is to demonstrate how Goethe and his works entered into the popular culture in the late nineteenth century and early decades of the twentieth. From costume jewelry to lithopanes to cigar boxes and candy wrappers, Goethe must have been present to the popular imagination, as reflected in the products and advertising of the period. Certain themes predominate in the collection: Faust in his study, Gretchen at her spinning wheel, Faust and Mephisto in conversation, Faust and Gretchen walking in the garden, Goethe and Schiller together—these iconic motifs recur again and again, on matchboxes, in wall hangings, on postcards, in jokes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Flat Objects, Paintings, Photographs and Illustrations, 1766-1999. II. Goethe in Adverstising, 1897-1949. III. Postcards and Commercial Photographs, 1897-1956. IV. Objects, 1897-1989. V. Posters and Broadsheets, 1897-1932.

German literature -- 18th century

controlaccess.persname: Goethe, Johann Wolfgang von, 1749-1832 ( Faust, Illustrations)

did.unittitle: Flat Objects, Paintings, Photographs and Illustrations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I. consists of two-dimensional printed ephemera, photographs and paintings relating to Goethe and Schiller, as well as flat wall hangings and plaques, leaves from Goethe and Schiller's coffins, a swatch of Schiller's waistcoat, pens used by Goethe, and an ivory carving of Schiller.

did.unittitle: German inflation money ("Notgeld")

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Currency printed by German cities during the inflation, all with quotations from Goethe or images relating to Goethe or his works Arranged partly by place of origin, partly by theme.

did.unittitle: Writing paper with Goethe motifs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One set, commemorating the centenary of Goethe's death in 1932, features photographs of Goethe sites and artifacts as well as a few contemporary photographs of members of Die Gesellschaft der Freunde Weimars, including one showing Elisabeth Förster-Nietzsche.

did.unittitle: Paper seals ("Siegelmarken")

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Seals intended to be affixed to letter envelopes, with themes relating to Goethe and Schiller.

did.unittitle: Postage stamps, postage cancellations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Assorted single stamps, sheets, and stamped envelopes with Goethe and Schiller themes.

did.unittitle: Coffin leaves

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Provenance: Accompanied by a note in William A. Speck's hand, "These leaves Frank Claudy, translator of 'Faust,' brought from Weimar. They were sent to me by his son." (Frank Claudy, 1844-1919).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ivy leaf from Schiller's coffin, 2 bay leaves from Goethe's coffin, and an unidentified pressed flower

did.unittitle: Bookplates

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bookplates with Goethe images or content, including a clipped facsimile of Goethe's book label and a commemorative set of bookplates from the Goethe year 1932.

did.unittitle: Goethe grapes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Colored print depicting the grape variety named for Goethe, one of several varieties created by E. S. Rogers in the mid nineteenth century, known as Rogers' Hybrids.

did.unittitle: Paper towels

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Provenance: Because the towels were apparently not distributed locally in Connecticut, the curator wrote to Georgia Pacific and asked for a roll of them, which was kindly sent by the manufacturer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Paper towels distributed under the Sparkle label by Georgia Pacific, printed with the quotation "Nothing is worth more than this day," attributed to Goethe. With an explanatory article in photocopy, "Goethe on a roll."

did.unittitle: Plaques for portraits

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brass plaques originally designed for the Oswald May portraits of Goethe and Wieland, now hanging in the north corridor, court level, of the Beinecke Library.

did.unittitle: Paper ephemera related to Goethe/Schiller coins and medals, early twentieth century

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Advertisements, rubbings, illustrations, photographs; some pieces relate to items in the Speck Collection.

did.unittitle: Calling cards and coats of arms

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes calling cards of Walther von Goethe and Wolfgang Freiherr von Goethe

did.unittitle: Textor, Johann Jost (1739-92). Printed ribbon celebrating his marriage to Maria Magdalena Möller on 17 February 1766
did.physdesc: 1 letter (6 pages on 3 leaves), and 1 ribbon

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Provenance: old note says that this was placed on deposit by Kurt Textor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pink ribbon, knotted in the middle, with four printed panels. Johann Jost Textor was Goethe's maternal uncle. With an ALS from Maria Textor to Carl Schreiber, 27 November 1936, describing a family ring and her current difficulties.

did.unittitle: Tintner, Hans. Die Jugendgeliebte (Goethes Frühlungstraum)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 15 photographs from the 1930s film, written and directed by Tintner (Atlantas-Film, Berlin)

did.unittitle: Schiller, Friedrich. A swatch from his last waistcoat

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lilac-colored silk cloth, with a signed authentication by Schiller's youngest daughter, Emilie von Gliechen Russwurm

did.unittitle: Goethe, Johann Wolfgang von. Three pens used by him

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three quills in a box with slipcase, with the inscription "Drey Federn, gebraucht bey Festgedichten Dec. 1818 Berga a.d. Ilm aufbewahrt durch Herren Schütz anerkannt Weimar Dec. 1827 von Goethe"

Faust and Gretchen embracing. Two lithophanes, one alabaster (?) in a wood frame, the other dark blue plastic-like material
Faust and Gretchen in the garden, oil painting
Faust and Gretchen in the street, colored print
Four photographs of a staging of Christian Dietrich Grabbe's Don Juan und Faust , Meiningen
Carving of Schiller's head, in profile, ivory, mounted in box

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Provenance: "Bequeathed by Mrs. Mary D. Turlay – received from Mrs. David T. Mackie (through Tiffany & Co) Nov. 26, 1921" Acquired in Heidelberg in the 1870s by Mrs. Mackie's mother.
Accompanied by letter from Isabel Mackie to Mr. Dana, 1921 November 22

did.unittitle: Goethe in Advertising

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A collection of labels, wrappers, clippings, advertising trade cards and other ephemera using Goethe quotations or motifs from his works (chiefly Faust) in advertising and the promotion of products. A few pieces depict Schiller or Schiller and Goethe. The material dates overwhelmingly from the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.

did.unittitle: Drinks, mineral waters & healthy potions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Including Sanatogen tonic, Henkell Trocken, and various wines

did.unittitle: Cigars and smoking
Cigar box labels, cigar bands, advertisements, matchbook
Two wooden cigar boxes ("Goethe" brand and "Margarethe" brand), a cigarette box, and two wax match boxes from around 1900 featuring scenes from Faust
Chocolate and other sweets

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Including Chocolade Marke "Gretchen" (Moser-Roth, Stuttgart) and Mignon Speise-Schokolade (David Söhne A,-G., Halle)

did.unittitle: Restaurants, hotels, and guesthouses

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Including the Goethe-Stube at the Hotel "goldener Adler" (Innsbruck) and various uses of Auerbachs Keller as a motif

did.unittitle: Books, bookstores, bookplates
Clothing, shoes, perfume, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Including packaging for Faust nail polish stones and advertisements for the "Dalli" self-heating flat iron, which feature a humorously updated Gretchen

did.unittitle: Calendars
Other products

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Including Gretchen Lockennadeln, Steiners Paradiesbett, fire extinguishers, drug stores, gas lighting ("Mehr Licht"), the Fränkische Butter-Centrale (Lotte cutting bread and butter), Schreibmachine "Ideal" ("Schreib deinen Pakt mit Seidel & Naumann's 'Ideal'"); Göthe-Feder, pen nibs made by Heintzel & Blanckertz (Berlin); and commemorative Meissen porcelain items.

did.unittitle: Unidentified products, clippings, quotations
Advertising trade cards with Goethe motifs
A. Zuntz sel. Wwe., gebrannte Caffees (Bonn, Berlin, and Hamburg)
American Tobacco Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "These pictures are packed in the brands of cigarettes manufactured by the American Tobacco Co."

Bouillon Cibils ( Hamburg)
Leibig Company's Fleisch-Extract (Antwerp and London), representing several series, in German and French
Sächsische Cartonnagen-Maschinen (Dresden)
Other firms

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Including Weber's Carlsbader Kaffeegewürz; Jordan & Timaeus Zuckerwaaren-Fabrik, Thee-Import (Dresden and Bodenbach); Stollwerck's Adler-Cacao; Hildebrands deutscher Kakao (Berlin); Moser-Roth Cacao (Stuttgart?); Kinder-Garderobe Heinrich Esders (Dresden); Petzold & Aulhorn, Edda-Chocolade (Dresden); C. Lück, Gesundheits-Kräuter-Honig (Colberg)

did.unittitle: Postcards and Commercial Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III. consists of postcards and commercially distributed photographs. Images are chiefly of characters in Faust, but there are also images of Goethe, Schiller, and places in Germany. Image formats include lithographs, photographic postcards, and carte-de-visite and cabinet card photographs.

did.unittitle: A collection of mostly early twentieth-century postcards relating to Goethe and Schiller, predominantly scenes from Goethe's Faust depicting Gretchen but also including places, portraits, and cards with purportedly humorous content

A collection of mostly early twentieth-century postcards relating to Goethe and Schiller, predominantly scenes from Goethe's Faust depicting Gretchen but also including places, portraits, and cards with purportedly humorous content
A small collection of commercial studio photographs, showing mostly various actresses portraying Gretchen, but including other subjects
Objects

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Objects consists of a wide range of three-dimensional items, including Goethe's grandfather's wax seal, images of Goethe reproduced in and on various media, figurines of characters from Faust, a fragment of Goethe's house, pressed flowers from Goethe's garden, a lock of Schiller's hair, a player piano roll, and fragments of the Berlin wall.

did.unittitle: Brooch depicting Gretchen and Faust, oval
Fragment from Goethe's family house in Frankfurt. Irregular piece of red brick.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Provenance: Gift of Dr. Arthur Burkhard

did.unittitle: Textor, Johann Wolfgang (1693-1771). His seal for embossing wax, oval

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Provenance: old note in a card file says that this was deposited by Kurt Textor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: J. W. Textor was Goethe's maternal grandfather.

did.unittitle: Snuff box with image of Goethe
Specimen of goethite (HFeO2), the mineral named for Goethe
Three miniatures on porcelain, two of Schiller, one of Goethe. (Goethe is badly chipped)
Schiller-Haar. Lock of blond hair, purportedly Schiller's, in a souvenir-type glass box (box is in poor condition)
Model of Goethe's family house in Frankfurt, metal, souvenir quality
"Schepp's Cake Box"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Metal box showing Goethe and Schiller, and scenes showing "Dorothea," "Lotte," and "Lili."

did.unittitle: Goethe statuette, porcelain. After Rauch.
Plaster plaques and profiles
Two identical round plaques showing Goethe ("Wolfgang von Göthe"), one painted dark brown, both chipped
Round plaque showing Goethe ("Iohann Wolfgang die Goethe aetatis suae LXVI Anno)
Round plaque showing Gellert, glazed
Two similar plaster silhouettes of Goethe's head in profile
Berlin wall. Small fragments

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Provenance: Gift of Wolfgang & Inge Braecklein, 1989

did.unittitle: Zwerger, A. Wood carving representing Mephistopheles.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Provenance: gift of Mrs. William A. Speck

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inscribed "A Zwerger, Salzburg"

did.unittitle: Mephistophles. Small wooden figurine, conical shape.
Set of Faust figurines. Jointed wooden figures on bases, 12-14 cm. high. Two representing Mephistopheles, two representing Faust, one representing Gretchen
Goethe demitasse cup and saucer (no mark)
Goethe bust. Small porcelain souvenir-type artifact, stamped "Germany" on the back.
Pressed flowers and leaves from Goethe's garden in Weimar and from other sites associated with Goethe.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Provenance: Almost certainly collected and preserved by William A. Speck on his second trip to Europe

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Loose between glass or sealed in glass mounts, most dated March or April 1897. The collection includes at least two examples of the "durch-gewachsene Rose," a rose in which stem and leaves grow out through the flower. Goethe used this phenomenon as evidence for his botanical theory that all parts of a flowering plant are morphological variations of the leaf.

did.unittitle: Gounod, Charles François. Faust Valse. Piano roll for player piano.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Paraphrase de Concert by Franz Liszt. New York: The Aeolian Company (Piano 9798).

did.unittitle: Wooden plaque with incised quotation from Goethe's letter to Lavater, 20 September 1780 ("Diese Begierde, die Pyramide meines Daseyns . . .")

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This plaque was almost surely part of a large sculpture acquired in the centenary year of Goethe's death and described by Carl Schreiber in the Report of the Librarian of Yale University, 1932-33, as an "Etruscan Goethe stele entitled Goethe Geist." The artist was the American sculptor Nat Smolin (1890-1950), then resident in Paris. This piece did not easily weather the vicissitudes of taste. The current curator has never seen it, its whereabouts being unknown to her. Her predecessor, Hedwig S. Dejon, used to say that the stele had been transferred to the Yale University Art Gallery for storage.

did.unittitle: Posters and Broadsheets

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V. consists of large-format posters advertising Goethe-related productions and events.

did.unittitle: Adolph Friedländer, Hamburg, printer. 4 large colored posters, early 20th century?
